**Summary of the Legal Case:**

**V.R. Holdings vs. Hero InvestCorp Limited & Anr. (C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 163/2021)**

**High Court of Delhi at New Delhi**

**Reserved on December 22, 2022; Pronounced on March 6, 2023**

**Background:**

The petitioner, V.R. Holdings, a partnership firm, sought the removal of the trade mark "HERO GROUP" registered in favor of the respondent, Hero InvestCorp Limited (HIL), under Class 10 for various medical and surgical instruments.

**Legal Issue:**

The main issue before the court was whether the registration of the "HERO GROUP" trade mark by HIL was legal, considering the Family Settlement Agreement (FSA) and Trade Mark and Name Agreement (TMNA) executed by the Munjal Group in 2010.

**Arguments:**

The petitioner argued that:

1. The FSA and TMNA assigned various trademarks to different family groups, which includes the "HERO" mark for medical instruments.
2. HIL was not a part of the assignment agreement and therefore has no right to use the "HERO GROUP" trade mark.
3. The FSA clauses 22.1 to 22.7 specifically state that any failure or delay in exercising rights shall not operate as a waiver, implying that HIL's non-assignment is an implied exclusion.

**Court Findings:**

The court held:

1. The petitioner had established prima facie that HIL was not entitled to use the "HERO GROUP" trade mark.
2. The TMNA excluded assignment of the trademark to anyone other than those specified, and HIL did not fall within that category.
3. The FSA's waiver clause (22.5) could not be read as an exemption for HIL from following the restrictions imposed in the TMNA.

**Decision:**

The High Court of Delhi ordered:

1. To cancel or vary the registration of the "HERO GROUP" trade mark under Class 10, in favor of HIL.
2. To remove the alleged trademark infringement by HIL from the Register of Trade Marks.
3. The matter to be heard again for further deliberation and final order on terms.

The Court found that it was necessary to cancel or vary the registration as per Section 57(1) of the Trademarks Act, 1999, due to contravention of trade mark rights by HIL through non-assigned use.
